journal-meta.journal-title: The American Journal of Sports Medicine

title-group.subtitle: Comparison of TightRope Fixation and Syndesmotic Screw Fixation for Accuracy of Syndesmotic Reduction

article-meta.aff: †Department of Trauma and Orthopaedics, Our Lady of Lourdes Hospital, Drogheda, Ireland
‡Department of Radiology, Our Lady of Lourdes Hospital, Drogheda, Ireland
§HRB Centre for Primary Care Research, Royal College of Surgeons in Ireland, Dublin, Ireland
Investigation performed at Department of Trauma and Orthopaedics, Department of Radiology, Our Lady of Lourdes Hospital, Drogheda, Republic of Ireland

author-notes.corresp: *Gohar A. Naqvi, MRCSI, MCh, 24 Crozon Crescent, Sligo, Republic of Ireland (e-mail: drgoharabbas@hotmail.com).

permissions.copyright-holder: American Orthopaedic Society for Sports Medicine

sec.title: Background:
sec.p: Ankle syndesmotic injuries are complex and require anatomic reduction and fixation to restore the normal biomechanics of the ankle joint and prevent long-term complications.

sec.title: Purpose:
sec.p: The aim of this study is to compare the accuracy and maintenance of syndesmotic reduction using TightRope versus syndesmotic screw fixation.

sec.title: Study Design:
sec.p: Cohort study; Level of evidence, 2.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: This cohort study included consecutive patients treated for ankle syndesmotic diastases between July 2007 and June 2009. Single slice axial computed tomography (CT) scans of both the ankles together were performed at the level of syndesmosis, 1 cm above the tibial plafond. A greater than 2-mm widening of syndesmosis compared with the untreated contralateral ankle was considered significant malreduction. Clinical outcomes were measured using the American Orthopaedics Foot and Ankle Society (AOFAS) and Foot and Ankle Disability Index (FADI) scores.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: Forty-six of 55 eligible patients participated in the study; 23 patients were in the TightRope group and 23 in the syndesmotic screw group. The average age was 42 years in the TightRope and 40 years in the syndesmotic screw group, and the mean follow-up time was 2.5 years (range, 1.5-3.5 years). The average width of normal syndesmosis was 4.03 ± 0.89 mm. In the TightRope group, the mean width of syndesmosis was 4.37 mm (SD, ±1.12 mm) (P = .30, t test) compared with 5.16 mm (SD, ±1.92 mm) in the syndesmotic screw group (P = .01, t test). Five of 23 ankles (21.7%) in the syndesmotic screw group had syndesmotic malreduction, whereas none of the TightRope group showed malreduction on CT scans (P = .04, Fisher exact test). Average time to full weightbearing was 8 weeks in the TightRope group and 9.1 weeks in the syndesmotic screw group. There was no significant difference between the TightRope and syndesmotic screw groups in mean postoperative AOFAS score (89.56 and 86.52, respectively) or FADI score (82.42 and 81.22, respectively). Regression analysis confirmed malreduction of syndesmosis as the only independent variable that affected the clinical outcome (regression coefficient, −12.39; t = −2.43; P = .02).

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: The results of this study indicate that fixation with TightRope provides a more accurate method of syndesmotic stabilization compared with screw fixation. Syndesmotic malreduction is the most important independent predictor of clinical outcomes; therefore, care should be taken to reduce the syndesmosis accurately.

body.p: Injuries to the distal tibiofibular syndesmosis are complex, and the diagnosis and management of such injuries pose a challenge to surgeons. In the United Kingdom, ankle fractures are the most common fractures among patients between 20 and 65 years, with a reported annual incidence of 90,000.22 It is estimated that 10% of all ankle fractures are associated with syndesmotic disruption.6 Although metal screw fixation has been the most popular stabilizing method used in ankle syndesmosis,7 a controversy still exists regarding the size and number of screws, number of cortices engaged, level of screw placement above the tibial plafond, need for routine removal, and timing of the screw removal.12,14,19 Malreduction of tibiofibular syndesmosis also has been reported to be a significant problem with screw fixation.11

The TightRope (Arthrex Inc, Naples, Florida) is a relatively new surgical implant based on the suture-Button design. It is a low-profile system consisting of a No. 5 FiberWire loop (Arthrex), which, when tensioned and secured between metallic EndoButtons placed against the outer cortices of the tibia and fibula, provides physiologic stabilization of the ankle mortise and obviates the need for a second procedure for routine removal; therefore, late diastasis is potentially unlikely.1 Biomechanical testing and clinical studies have shown equivalent strength and improved patient outcome with the TightRope technique.18,21 The literature referring to TightRope fixation is rather limited, and the issue of malreduction has not been extensively investigated. In almost all published studies thus far, syndesmotic reduction has been assessed based on radiographic parameters, including medial clear space, tibiofibular clear space, and tibiofibular overlap, on standard ankle radiographs.3-5,8,16,20,25 A published study has indicated that radiographic measurements are influenced by ankle rotation and are, therefore, inaccurate.2 Significant malreduction of the tibiofibular syndesmosis has been reported in the literature for patients treated with the syndesmotic screw.11,24 Because malreduction of the syndesmosis is the most important independent predictor of long-term functional outcome,23 this study primarily aims to compare the accuracy and maintenance of syndesmotic reduction using TightRope versus syndesmotic screw fixation and its correlation with clinical outcomes.

sec.title: Study Design
sec.p: A cohort study was conducted to assess the radiological and clinical outcomes of patients after the treatment of ankle injuries involving distal tibiofibular syndesmosis. Two different methods of syndesmotic fixation were compared (the standard transosseous syndesmotic screw fixation method and the relatively new TightRope fixation technique) to assess the accuracy and maintenance of syndesmotic reduction and its correlation with functional outcome scores at least 18 months after surgery. We examined the accuracy of syndesmotic reduction assessed primarily on axial computed tomography (CT) scans of the ankles using the uninjured contralateral ankle as a control. The study was approved by the institutional review board, and written informed consent was obtained from all patients included in the study. We followed the STROBE (Strengthening the Reporting of Observational Studies in Epidemiology) guidelines in conducting this study.

sec.title: Selection of Patients
sec.p: This cohort study included all consecutive adult patients treated for acute ankle syndesmotic diastases with either the TightRope or the syndesmotic screw fixation method in our regional trauma center over a period of 2 years, between July 2007 and June 2009. Patients with compound fractures, multiple injuries, neuropathic arthropathy, bilateral injuries, and chronic or missed syndesmotic injuries were excluded.

sec.title: Treatment and Follow-up
sec.p: Three consultants used the screw fixation method, whereas the other 3 consultants used the TightRope technique for all of their patients requiring syndesmotic fixation irrespective of age, sex, and the type of associated fractures. The diagnosis of tibiofibular diastasis was based on both clinical examination and radiographic parameters, including widening of the tibiofibular clear space and reduction of tibiofibular overlap preoperatively, followed by intraoperative confirmation under the image intensifier using the external rotation stress test or hook test. Concomitant fractures of the fibula and medial malleolus were fixed according to standard principles of the Association for the Study of Internal Fixation (AO-ASIF). Ankle syndesmoses were stabilized with either the transosseous syndesmotic screw (Synthes, Inc, Oberdorf, Switzerland) or the TightRope system, depending on the surgeon’s preference. All patients were immobilized in a below-the-knee, nonweightbearing cast for 6 weeks, followed by physical therapy and weightbearing as tolerated. Patients were followed up in the clinic at 2 weeks, at 6 weeks, and then after 3 months. In this cohort of patients, the syndesmotic screws were routinely removed at approximately 10 weeks after surgery. Patients were reviewed at least 18 months after surgery for study data collection.

sec.title: Surgical Techniques
sec.p: All procedures were performed with patients in the supine position under general or spinal anesthesia with antibiotic prophylaxis and tourniquet control. Standard ankle orthosis techniques were used to internally fix fractures of the fibula or tibia requiring fixation, and a large ankle orthosis clamp with the ankle in neutral position was used to reduce and maintain syndesmosis. Reduction was confirmed under image intensifier. All 4 cortices were drilled from the fibular side, angled 30° anterior to the coronal plane, and placed approximately 2.5 cm above and parallel to the tibial plafond. If a plate was used for fibular stabilization, the drill hole was made through one of the empty plate holes, depending on the location of the plate. In patients treated with a syndesmotic screw, either a 3.5-mm or a 4.5-mm cortical screw was inserted through the drill hole, engaging all 4 cortices. In the TightRope group, the needle attached to the leading oblong Button was passed through the holes and out from the intact medial skin along with the pull-through sutures. Once the medial button was passed through the medial tibial cortex (confirmed by imaging), the assembly was tensioned by pulling the free ends of the FiberWire on the lateral side. Once both the buttons were seated flush with the bone, the free ends of the FiberWire were hand tied on the lateral side and cut 1 cm long and buried. Two TightRopes were used in 7 cases and 2 syndesmotic screws in 3 cases depending on the fracture configuration.

sec.title: Assessment
sec.p: All participants underwent a clinical examination by an independent clinician who was blinded for the type of syndesmotic fixation. Radiographic assessment included an anteroposterior (AP) radiograph of the ankle and a single-slice axial CT scan of both the ankles together, at 1 cm above the tibial plafond. All of the CT scans were performed by a single, senior CT radiographer using predetermined parameters. To standardize the measurements, a survey scan was performed with both of the ankles together in the supine position with the ankles in neutral position, and a 1-cm distance was measured from the tibial plafond to obtain the axial CT scan image (Figure 1).

caption.p: Survey computed tomography scan image of the operated and contralateral ankles of a patient treated with TightRope fixation through a 1/3 tubular plate for a Weber C ankle fracture. A marker for the axial CT scan slice was placed after a distance of approximately 1 cm from tibial plafond was measured.

sec.title: Outcome Variables and Measurements
sec.p: Accuracy of the syndesmotic reduction on axial CT scans was considered the primary outcome variable for comparison of the 2 treatment options. The criterion for malreduction of syndesmosis was set at >2 mm of difference in the width of the syndesmosis compared with the untreated contralateral ankle, as measured on the axial CT scan. The criterion was set at >2 mm in accordance with previous literature11 and the assumption that this difference will result in a sufficient level of joint incongruity, which may lead to increased contact pressures in the ankle joint and the risk of early degenerative changes.13,17 Elgafy et al10 reported that the average posterior width of syndesmoses is 4 mm (standard deviation [SD], ±1.19 mm). Because this area corresponds to the tibiofibular clear space on AP radiographs and >6 mm of tibiofibular clear space is considered abnormal, the criterion of >2 mm is justified.

The width of the posterior portion of the syndesmotic joint space was measured to facilitate this comparison, because this corresponds to the tibiofibular clear space on the AP radiographs. The distance was measured from the posterior tibial tubercle to the medial boarder or the nearest point on the fibula (Figures 2 and 3).

caption.p: Axial computed tomography scan of the untreated ankle showing the cross-sectional anatomy of the tibia and fibula at the level of the syndesmosis. The anterior and posterior tubercles of the tibia are used as reference points for syndesmotic measurements. Note also the 4 borders of the fibula: a, anterior; p, posterior; i, interosseous; m, medial.

Measurements for the width of the syndesmosis on an axial computed tomography scan of both ankles of the same patient as in Figure 1 showing the anterior (bottom measurements) and posterior (top measurements) width of the syndesmosis.

sec.p: We also assessed syndesmotic reduction on AP radiographs of the ankle using parameters including tibiofibular clear space <6 mm, tibiofibular overlap >6 mm, and medial clear space <5 mm. All the measurements were taken by an independent radiologist with special interest in musculoskeletal radiology, using digital imaging software.

Clinical outcomes were compared using the American Orthopaedics Foot and Ankle Society (AOFAS) score, the Foot and Ankle Disability Index (FADI) score, time to full weightbearing, and the rate of complications. Both AOFAS and FADI scores range from 0 to 100, with higher scores indicating better function.

sec.title: Sample Size Estimation
sec.p: Sample size calculation was performed based on the measurements of normal syndesmosis on the CT scan as reported by Elgafy et al.10 The mean width of syndesmosis was noted to be 4 mm (SD, ±1.19 mm). Based on a 2-group comparison, power calculations indicated that a minimum of 46 participants (23 in each group) were required to detect a difference of 1 mm in the CT measurements, at a 2-sided significance level of 5% and a power of 80%, assuming an SD of ±1.19 mm.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: Statistical analysis was confirmed using Stata 11.1 statistical software (StataCorp, College Station, Texas). Demographics were compared for the 2 groups using mean values and proportions. Mean values were also calculated for the CT and radiographic parameters for both operated and contralateral ankles in 2 groups separately, and a t test was used for comparison of these values within each group to measure statistical significance. The Fisher exact test was used to analyze data regarding malreduction of syndesmosis to calculate relative risk and statistical significance. Regression analysis was performed to adjust for potential confounders such as patient age and the duration since the index procedure and to find the variables affecting the clinical outcome scores.

sec.title: Patient Demographics and Injury Classification
sec.p: Of the 228 consecutive patients undergoing surgery for ankle fractures during the 2-year study period (between July 2007 and June 2009), 61 patients had associated syndesmotic injuries and were potentially eligible for inclusion in the study. Six were excluded, based on study exclusion criteria. Fifty-five patients were finally invited to participate in the study; 46 patients attended for the final review and CT scans and were included in the final analysis (Figure 4). There were 23 patients in the TightRope group and 23 in the syndesmotic screw group; their mean ages were 41.65 years and 39.82 years, respectively. Summary data regarding patient demographics, mechanisms of injury, and fracture classification are presented in Table 1.

caption.p: Flow chart showing selection of patients. Pt, patient.

tr.td: Distance from tibial plafond, mean (range), mm

sec.title: Computed Tomographic Measurements
sec.p: Comparison of the width of the syndesmosis between the operated and contralateral ankles showed mean ± SD values of 4.37 ± 1.12 mm for the operated side and 4.04 ± 0.95 mm for the contralateral side in the TightRope group (P = .30, t test). In the syndesmotic screw group, the mean width of the syndesmosis was 5.16 ± 1.92 mm on the operated side and 4.02 ± 0.87 mm on the contralateral side (P = 0.01, t test) (Table 2, Figure 5).

caption.p: Comparison of Syndesmotic Width Between the Operated and Contralateral Ankle in the 2 Groupsa

fn.label: a
fn.p: Values are expressed as mean ± standard deviation (range). A P value <.05 is considered statistically significant.

caption.p: Box plot comparing the syndesmotic width of the operated and contralateral ankles. Note the obvious wide range of syndesmotic width on the operated side in the syndesmotic screw group.

sec.p: The primary outcome measure, malreduction of syndesmosis, was diagnosed on the basis of the predefined criterion of a >2 mm difference in width from the contralateral side (Table 3). No case of malreduction was observed in the TightRope group. However, of the 23 ankles in the syndesmotic screw group, 5 (21.7%) showed malreduction of the syndesmosis (P = .04, Fisher exact test) (Figure 6). The risk of malreduction was 21.7% higher in the syndesmotic screw group than in the TightRope group.

caption.p: Malreduction of Syndesmosis Between the TightRope and Syndesmotic Screw Groupsa

fn.label: a
fn.p: Malreduction was diagnosed on the basis of predefined criteria of a >2 mm difference between treated and untreated sides. P < .05, Fisher exact test.

caption.p: Malreduction of syndesmosis. Axial computed tomography scan of both the ankles of a patient in syndesmotic screw group, showing malreduction of syndesmosis in right ankle.

sec.title: Radiographic Measurements
sec.p: Mean preoperative and postoperative values are compared in Table 4. According to the radiographic criterion of syndesmotic integrity on plain film radiographs, 9 patients had syndesmotic malreduction. Only 3 patients with true malreduction on the CT scan were correctly diagnosed using radiographic parameters, whereas 6 had a false-positive result (Table 5).

caption.p: Preoperative and Postoperative Radiographic Parameters of Syndesmosisa

fn.label: a
fn.p: Values are expressed as mean ± standard deviation (range) in millimeters. Pre, preoperative; post, postoperative.

caption.p: Comparison of CT Scan and Radiographs for Diagnosis of Syndesmotic Malreductiona

fn.label: a
fn.p: The radiographic criteria for syndesmotic malreduction included tibiofibular clear space >6 mm or tibiofibular overlap <6 mm on standard anteroposterior ankle radiographs. On computed tomography (CT) scans, malreduction was diagnosed if there was >2 mm difference in the width of syndesmosis compared with the contralateral side.

sec.title: Clinical Outcomes
sec.p: The mean time to full weightbearing was 8 weeks (range, 6-10 weeks) in the TightRope group compared with 9.1 weeks (range, 6-13 weeks) in the syndesmotic screw group (P = .11). The mean AOFAS and FADI scores as shown in Table 6 were comparable in both groups.

fn.label: a
fn.p: Values are expressed as mean ± standard deviation (range) unless otherwise indicated. AOFAS, American Orthopaedics Foot and Ankle Society; FADI, Foot and Ankle Disability Index.

sec.p: Regression analysis showed that type of fixation, age, and duration since surgery did not significantly affect the clinical outcome scores. Malreduction of syndesmosis was the only independent variable that reached statistical significance, with a regression coefficient of −12.39 (t = −2.43; P = .02) (Table 7).

caption.p: Regression Analysis to Determine the Predictors of Functional Outcomea

fn.label: a
fn.p: The American Orthopaedics Foot and Ankle Society score is used in this regression analysis as the measure of functional outcome.

fn.label: b
fn.p: Syndesmotic malreduction is the only independent predictor of worse functional outcome score. A regression coefficient of −12.39 indicates that the presence of malreduction in this study resulted in reduction of 12.39 points on the outcome score.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This study compared the accuracy and maintenance of syndesmotic reduction based on CT scans and their correlation with the clinical outcomes. The results of this study indicated a significant difference in the mean width of the syndesmosis between operated and contralateral ankles in the syndesmotic screw group compared with the TightRope group. Although a trend toward better clinical outcomes in the TightRope group was noted, when it was adjusted for potential confounders, including age and time period since surgery, no statistically significant difference was seen in the functional outcome scores (AOFAS, FADI). Malreduction of the syndesmosis was the only independent variable that significantly affected the functional outcome scores.

According to our criterion of malreduction, 5 cases of malreduction were identified in the syndesmotic screw group, whereas there were none in the TightRope group. A 21.7% increased risk that syndesmosis would be malreduced with the screw fixation method was observed rather than with the TightRope technique (P < .05, Fisher exact test). This concurs with the earlier literature regarding syndesmotic screw fixation. The incidence of malreduction of syndesmosis has been reported to be between 16% and 52%.11,15,23,24 Weening and Bhandari23 reported 16% malreduction of syndesmosis in patients treated with the syndesmotic screw. The diagnosis of malreduction in that study was based on the standard radiographic parameters of syndesmotic integrity and demonstrated a direct relation of malreduction with poor functional outcome scores. Because the literature has suggested that standard radiographic measurements are inaccurate2,9 and insufficient to diagnose syndesmotic malreduction, several authors have used CT scans to improve the diagnostic accuracy. Gardner et al11 reported 52% syndesmotic malreduction in their series of 25 patients treated with the syndesmotic screw based on CT scans, compared with only 24% based on standard radiographic criteria. This is the highest incidence of malreduction reported thus far in the literature, although the validity of the results is limited by the lack of comparison with the uninjured ankle and the absence of clinical correlation. Wikeroy et al24 reviewed 48 patients treated with the syndesmotic screw from an earlier randomized controlled study after 8.4 years and reported a 20.8% incidence of malreduction based on an axial CT scan compared with the contralateral side. Concurrent with the findings of Wikeroy et al,24 the present study showed a 21.7% incidence of malreduction in the syndesmotic screw group.

The TightRope fixation for syndesmotic injury is a relatively new technique that provides dynamic fixation and obviates the need for routine implant removal. The literature is rather limited regarding the TightRope technique and mainly consists of a few case series and nonrandomized comparative studies with limited numbers of patients and shorter follow-up periods. Thornes et al20 and Cottom et al4 compared the suture–EndoButton technique (Smith & Nephew Inc, Andover, Massachusetts) and syndesmotic screw fixation method in a nonrandomized comparative study and reported a trend toward better functional outcomes with the suture–EndoButton technique. Thornes et al20 also performed a CT scan in 11 of 16 patients in the suture–EndoButton group after 3 months and did not report any loss of reduction. None of the patients in their syndesmotic screw group underwent a CT scan, which limited the significance of that part of the study. Coetzee and Ebeling3 reported a similar trend of better clinical outcomes in their preliminary results of a randomized controlled trial.

The present study is the only one that has comparatively studied the accuracy and maintenance of syndesmotic reduction between the TightRope and syndesmotic screw, and it showed that the TightRope fixation technique was significantly better at maintaining the reduction, even after a mean duration of 30 months after surgery. The reason for the high incidence of malreduction in the syndesmotic screw group is, however, difficult to determine from this study, because CT scans were not performed immediately postoperatively, which makes it difficult to discern exactly when the diastases occurred (ie, whether the syndesmoses were malreduced at the time of surgery or had evolved over time). The possibility of an increased gap after removal of the syndesmotic screw cannot be ruled out either. However, the TightRope technique does not require routine removal and continues to maintain reduction. Because TightRope is a flexible device, one possible explanation for the accurate reduction is that the fibula is pulled into the concave incisura fibularis of the distal tibia as it is tightened.

Some limitations in this study need to be considered. First, this was a nonrandomized study and as such has inherent limitations, such as risk of selection bias and performance bias, because the procedures were performed by different surgeons. Blinding of the primary outcome assessor was not possible. Second, it was not possible to identify the precise reason for the higher incidence of malreduction in the syndesmotic screw group. Despite these limitations, given the appropriate size of the sample and follow-up duration, the results of the study are potentially valid and show that TightRope fixation is at least equivalent to the conventional screw fixation in the treatment of syndesmotic injuries and that it has the potential advantages of providing and maintaining accurate reduction and avoiding the need for routine removal. The technique is simple and can be used both in isolation and with plate fixation. Further long-term randomized controlled trials are desirable to confirm the results.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Ankle syndesmotic injuries are complex and require accurate reduction and fixation to restore the normal biomechanics of the ankle joint and avoid long-term complications. Syndesmotic screw and TightRope fixation are both valid options for the treatment of syndesmotic injuries. Although short- to medium-term clinical results are comparable for both the groups, TightRope provides and maintains more accurate reduction of syndesmosis compared with screw fixation and obviates the need for routine implant removal. Because malreduction of syndesmosis is the most important independent predictor of long-term functional outcome in these injuries,23 care must be taken to accurately reduce the syndesmosis before fixation.

fn.p: The authors declared that they have no conflicts of interest in the authorship and publication of this contribution.
